column1: Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is the amount of salt (sodium) that leaves the body through urine compared to the amount filtered and reabsorbed by the kidney.
Instead it is a calculation based on the concentrations of sodium and creatinine in the blood and urine.
There, they are examined for salt (sodium) and creatinine levels.
For example, some diuretic medicines (water pills) can affect test results.
The test is usually done for persons who are very ill with acute kidney disease.
